urn:contentItem:5XW7-J3B1-DXH2-60G4-00000-00THE BEAT WITH ARI MELBER; December 31, 20192019-12-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:30ZLexisNexisTHE BEAT WITH ARI MELBER6:00 PM ESTTim Lewis, Byron DorganNEWSDomestic123101cb.457THE BEAT WITH ARI MELBER; December 31, 2019Ari Melber

Historic: Trump impeached, Senate preps for trial; House impeaches Trump, Chief Justice Roberts to oversee Senate trial; Assessing the Senate trial of President Trump; Interview with Former Independent Counsel Ken Starr on impeachment and whether a sitting President can be indicted; One- on-one with Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-MA) about her vision for 2020 and breaking up big tech; Favorite moments from "Maverick" series.

(REPEAT OF 12/24 SHOW)

ARI MELBER, ANCHOR MSNBC: Good evening, and welcome to a holiday edition of "The Beat." We actually have some very special things planned for you tonight. Americans have been, of course, now leaning into the holidays, stepping back from a year where Donald Trump`s actions certainly caught up with him, facing a December impeachment, an existential crisis for the Trump Presidency after a news year consumed by his mistakes and scandals.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

REP. NANCY PELOSI (D-CA): I`m announcing the House of Representatives moving forward with an official impeachment inquiry.

MELBER: They are under fire from all sides for this whistleblower complaint.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: What exactly did you hope Zelensky would do about the Bidens after your phone call?

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT, UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: They`d start a major investigation into the Bidens.

MELBER: Donald Trump busted for making good on his infamous claim he would take foreign help in 2020.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Impeachment is imperative.

MELBER: --that the President committed crimes in office.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: So you say impeach?

MELBER: So that is a thing.

The case for bribery is straightforward. And everyone knows bribery is impeachable.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: And that`s why we held up the money. We do that all the time with foreign policy.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: But to be clear, you just described is a quid pro quo.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Tell me what rule, law or statute has been violated by the President--

MELBER: Do you want to point to statutes? That`s not required, but it is--

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Oh, yes, but tell me about the--

MELBER: Hold on. And then I`ll you respond, sir. It is unlawful to solicit or receive any foreign help, which includes things of value.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I think what it - I think, for a citizen, it set off some alarms.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Because that`s obviously shady?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes, it`s pretty damning evidence.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Damning slam dunk evidence.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: An incredibly damning admission that you can`t trust the President not to commit crimes.

REP. ADAM SCHIFF (D-CA): It goes right to the heart of the issue of bribery.

PELOSI: That`s it. It`s perfectly wrong. It`s bribery.

MELBER: A week unlike any other in the Trump era. Nine different Trump administration insiders who joined 12 other witnesses who`ve now provided over 30 hours of testimony in the--

GORDON SONDLAND, UNITED STATES AMBASSADOR TO THE EUROPEAN UNION: Was there a quid pro quo? The answer is yes.

MELBER (voice-over): Here is the most important shift in all the testimony to-date. Sondland moves over, suddenly saying, yes, this was bribery.

FIONA HILL, FORMER TOP RUSSIA EXPERT AT U.S. NATIONAL SECURITY COUNCIL: He was being involved in a domestic political errand. And we were being involved in national security foreign policy. And those two things had just diverged.

SONDLAND: Everyone was in the loop.

MELBER: His personal attorney, Rudy Giuliani, is in Ukraine today, of all places. He says he`s meeting with prosecutors, which are of course also potential witnesses.

To paraphrase Biggie Smalls, he is going going back back to Kyiv Kyiv.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This is a crime spree in progress. And that gives us an urgency to act.

MELBER: Rudy Giuliani is pulling off--

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes.

MELBER: Getting Donald Trump impeached.

The House will do what many thought it was on its way to do, impeach President Trump, starting now.

PELOSI: I`m asking our Chairman to proceed with articles of impeachment.

REP. ILHAN OMAR (D-MN): This lawless President has taken advantage of the public trust.

REP. JERRY NADLER (D-NY): --committing high crimes and misdemeanors.

MELBER: You absolutely have a Constitution that provides for a very quick remedy to that.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We`ve got President Trump who`s basically out-Nixoning Nixon.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: An extraordinary breach of the powers of the Presidency.

MELBER: It is a vote that actually changes everything.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MELBER: The trial of Donald J. Trump is the first impeachment trial in a generation, and there are civics lessons here. The Constitution mandating Chief Justice John Roberts will preside with all senators serving as jurors. And other key calls are still wide open right now because when you understand the rules, you understand they can change any time.

I`m joined now by Judge Tim Lewis, appointed to the federal bench by President George H.W. Bush, and Former Senator Byron Dorgan from North Dakota. He served during the Clinton impeachment trial and voted not-guilty on both counts. A very special, and as I`ve emphasized, rare to have a Federal Appeals judge and a senator here together in this discussion.

Thanks to both of you.

TIM LEWIS, FORMER UNITED STATES CIRCUIT JUDGE: Thank you, Ari.

BYRON DORGAN, FORMER SENATOR FROM NORTH DAKOTA: Thank you.

LEWIS: Happy to be here.

MELBER: Appreciate it.

Judge, let`s begin with you. What would define a fair trial of a President in the Senate?

LEWIS: That`s a - that`s a good question. There have been so few that we really kind of have to look at history and look forward, as you mentioned earlier, to the legacy that might be left to determine how best to perform, I think, as both senators and as the Chief Justice presiding.

I think that primarily we are looking for a decorum that rises above partisan politics to the extent possible in order to ensure that the American people get what they deserve, which is a fair look at whatever the charges are - that are brought by the Congress in the form of an impeachment might be. And we don`t know what those are at this point.

I think that in addition, the Chief Justice is going to have to adjust to a different environment. I`m not sure he`s exactly relishing presiding at an impeachment trial. As you know, the Supreme Court has no cameras. It`s a very different culture and a different environment. And so his presence and how he conducts business is going to also lend some definition to fairness and how things unfold.

MELBER: Let me - let me ask you about that. As a fellow judge, do you think this could become one of the most important things Chief Justice John Roberts ever does?

LEWIS: Well, as you know, the Supreme Court takes up the seminal issues in cases that we have to address as a society. So I`m not sure that I would go quite that far. But it certainly is a solemn responsibility. And it`s - as I said, it`s in a forum with which he does not have direct familiarity.

So I think that learning about the rules of the Senate, the rules of - their specific rules governing the Senate impeachment process, relying on the parliamentarian for some insight and advice, and really letting the senators take center stage as opposed to the Chief Justice to do what they must do, hoping that they will rise to the occasion. I mean, the whole world is watching. The whole country is watching. And it`s only charges against the President of the United States that could very well result in his removal. So--

MELBER: Let me bring in the Senator on that point. I mean, Senator Dorgan, whatever one`s views of the case, which by that time was I reached the Senate, the Clinton scandals had been well-debated in American life.

DORGAN: Right.

MELBER: Did you, did your colleagues, did you see anyone walk out of the Senate floor as the trial actually commenced and hit and felt the gravity - we just showed some of the clips - where they said, wait, this is a big one?

DORGAN: Yes. I mean, I think everybody understood this is a very sober moment. There is no joy in a United States Senate that convenes as a trial for a prosecution of impeachment resolution. It is a tough situation. Let me just tell you that as we began - there`s not much of a template for how you proceed. As we began, we - all 100 of us met in the old Senate chambers and had an off-the-record discussion about how do we do this. I mean, what`s the template by which we do this?

Some, for example, wanted to call witnesses into the chamber of the Senate. Bring Monica Lewinsky in, some of them said, so that she can be a witness and the - well, the fact is that was discarded, and ultimately we`ve got videotapes and they were able to present videotapes.

But - so we went to the Senate floor as a trial, as a - and we had to be sworn in separately as jurors. We had to sign an oath. And as you saw on the video, the Chief Justice was there in his black robe where there`s gold stripes on the arms. And we started. And it was very difficult. I mean, it went for - it started on January 7th 20 years ago and completed I think on February 12th--

(CROSSTALK)

MELBER: Did that private room meeting that you`re referencing? Did it have, by the end, a consensus?

DORGAN: It did. And interestingly enough, the consensus was reached, as I recall, principally by Ted Kennedy and Phil Graham, very different people with very different--

MELBER: No kidding.

DORGAN: --political perspectives. And so we came out of that old Senate chamber with an understanding of how we should proceed. And not everything went smoothly, but by and large, it was a very sober time.

MELBER: Senator Dorgan, we pulled some of the then U.S. Senator Dorgan on the day of the acquittal. Take a look.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DORGAN: Every member of the Senate feels strongly about the President`s conduct, but I think that the Constitution worked today. The United States Senate decided not to nullify the last election in this country as a result of the charges that were brought against this President.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MELBER: The issue is maybe very different--

DORGAN: You know--

MELBER: --but eagle-eyed viewers will note your reference to not nullifying the past election is what--

DORGAN: You`re right--

MELBER: --what the President - the President`s lawyers have said this week about this effort.

DORGAN: But especially, not nullifying the election over personal behavior. That`s what this was about. This was about personal behavior, abhorrent as it was. But that`s vastly different than behavior in which a President is asking a foreign government to intervene and to involve themselves in an election here in this country. That, by the way, is criminal. So - I mean, there`s a lot of evidence that some really bad things have been happening and have happened. And I think this Senate will have to deal with those questions.

MELBER: Yes.

DORGAN: And they are not questions about personal behavior.

MELBER: Judge Lewis, there`s a question I have for you I`ve been waiting to ask all week since I had the opportunity to read the President`s lawyer Jay Sekulow early this week. He is taking the public position that it would be unfair, as a matter of general due process, to try to convict a President on anonymous testimony, people who can`t be confronted.

Now, we all know - I think most people, we all know the rules are different. There`s no Constitutional requirement of what merits due process. But what do you think about the substance of that argument? Do you think there`s fairness there? Would it concern you to remove any President if it was primarily on anonymous testimony?

MELBER: Look, the Constitution vests the authority to remove a President, exclusively in the United States Senate. And other than that, it does not spell out any specific guarantees of due process or some amorphous notion of fairness although we do hope that it is a fair process and procedure. It`s a political process by nature. That argument does not work, and it will not work. No.

The country really deserves a full airing of all of the charges that may be brought, whatever they might be and wherever they might lead. And we have reposed in our representatives the solemn responsibility to rise above politics to the extent possible and to do what they must do, what they`ve taken an oath to do, and uphold the Constitution.

You had an earlier clip, Ari, in which you played that segment from the Watergate hearings when Barbara Jordan spoke. And her words give me chills every time I hear them. My faith in the Constitution is complete. My faith in the Constitution is complete, too, but it is only as good and it will only rise to the level that we hope and expect to the extent that our representatives are able to do their job and to assume their oaths.

And so, no, I`m - it`s not an - it`s not an argument that is recognized in the Constitution. As you know, there are no rules of criminal procedure, civil procedure. This is a very unique proceeding. When--

MELBER: Yes.

LEWIS: --the Senate is convened for this proceeding, it is convened as a court--

MELBER: Yes.

LEWIS: --as a court of impeachment. And so they will determine--

MELBER: Right.

LEWIS: --what the rules are and how things unfold.

MELBER: Clarity, expertise, wisdom. I can`t say we get that all day every day from Washington, but we`ve certainly got it from both of you, Judge Lewis, Former Senator Dorgan. Thanks to both of you.

LEWIS: Thanks, Ari.

DORGAN: Thank you, sir.

MELBER: And coming up next, my interview with Ken Starr himself. We talk impeachment and whether a sitting President can be indicted. Later, what Elizabeth Warren is saying about her vision for 2020 and breaking up big tech. Then, when we get to the end of this hour, we`re going to have some of our very favorite moments from our "Maverick" series with Lee Daniels and Annie Lennox, and more of all of that. Plus, some lighter moments from "The Beat" coming up.

MELBER: Donald Trump`s Senate trial comes two decades after the trial of Bill Clinton. No one loomed larger over that trial than Independent Counsel Ken Starr who drove the investigation that led to impeachment, testified as a witness in the House hearings and even returned during the Senate trial to interview Monica Lewinsky again.

Starr ultimately faced criticism not only from Democrats but from many independent analysts and legal experts over his approach. He remains, still though, one of the few living figures who have run this kind of investigation that leads to a President`s Senate trial, which makes him very interesting to talk with.

And we got to do that this year, as Mueller was still writing his report. Tonight, we want to show you just a few quick highlights with some points that echo harshly for Donald Trump, as we talked witness tampering, Starr`s view on whether sitting presidents can be indicted. One of the issues that would soon hobble Trump, Congress`s power to impeach for obstruction.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MELBER: When I say obstruction, I mean, something that the Congress, about a president, might find to be obstructive and impeach over.

KEN STARR, FORMER UNITED STATES SOLICITOR GENERAL & FORMER INDEPENDENT COUNSEL: Oh, yes, because Congress is not limited to these very technical elements, as you well know, with respect of what constitutes obstruction of justice.

MELBER: So those things you think Congress could impeach a president over if they found a pattern of obstruction?

STARR: Congress has clean area (ph) power under the Constitution, as I see it. It can say this is simply taken as a whole, the course of conduct constitutes an abuse of power.

MELBER: Abuse of power. What about discouraging witnesses from cooperating with law enforcement?

STARR: Once again, that could be an actual crime. Discouraging witnesses could, in fact, constitute intimidation of witnesses. For impeachment, again, Ari, I want to draw a line--

MELBER: Sure.

STARR: --between what Congress could say this is conduct that we don`t accept as opposed to here`s a criminal offense. It doesn`t, in my judgment, need to rise to the level of a technical crime under obstruction of justice.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STARR: We concluded that perjury and obstruction of justice, like bribery, may constitute grounds for an impeachment.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MELBER: Are you in a position now where people will question whether you`re applying a different standard to this President who happens to be in your party and the President you investigated who happened to be in the other party?

STARR: No, because it began with actual perjury, and we believe intimidation of witnesses in a judicial proceeding. So that`s another aspect of this. What the President had to face - what President Clinton had to face was a civil action, a civil rights action, and he had to then be honest. He could settle the case, which he should have done, or then he had to conduct himself lawfully, and he did not. And I don`t think anyone seriously disputes that he not only committed perjury, he encouraged others to lie.

And then here was the crescendo, what we reached, and this was with the complete agreement of the legendary at the time, Sam Dash, now departed, who was in the Watergate episode as a special counsel to Senator Sam Ervin. And all of this led up to abuse of power.

One of the messages as you`ll get there is impeachment is hell. We lived through that as a country 20 years ago. And so I think it requires--

MELBER: You`re saying you put us through hell.

STARR: I`m saying the House of Representatives took the evidence and said, we have a duty to do what we feel like what--

(CROSSTALK)

MELBER: Well you - if that`s what you had them do. I mean, you wrote a report for them to impeach.

STARR: I didn`t - I gave them that - Ari, this is great. Ari, I--

MELBER: This is great?

STARR: It is.

MELBER: Ken Starr on live TV saying that you didn`t give them information to lead to impeachment?

STARR: No. You - you had a very different characterization to the question. So roll it back. Roll the transcript back. And now I will answer the question--

(CROSSTALK)

MELBER: I got to tell you. I feel like I`m talking to a lawyer.

(LAUGHTER)

MELBER: Go ahead, sir.

STARR: Well, so am I. So what the statute - and this is one of the defects of the statute, and it`s no longer a defect that Bob Mueller has to live with, is that the statute set the bar very low for providing information that may constitute grounds for impeachment. That`s what the Congress required the Independent Counsel to do. So the report that went up was precisely that, which Congress in 1978 said that`s what we want.

Ari, the good news is, for the country, we don`t have that regime anymore.

MELBER: You`re saying - and I`m characterizing - but you`re saying the good news is we`ll never have another Ken Starr investigation?

STARR: We will have no - well, you could also ask Judge Walsh and so forth. So I--

MELBER: Which I`m asking you.

STARR: I`d prefer that you not personalize it and make it more structural because the statute created - well, there were about 20 independent counsels over the course of that 21 years.

MELBER: But yours was the one at your tenure that led to that impeachment that you are calling hell, that you`re right. Obviously, the underlying law was strong, as I mentioned earlier. So it put that information, but you wrote that report.

Let`s also get to something very interesting that you know is hot today. You solicited an opinion for your investigation that argued a sitting president could be indicted. Did you agree with that view then?

STARR: Yes.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MELBER: Now, when we come back in 30 seconds, my interview with Senator Elizabeth Warren.

MELBER: Welcome back to our holiday special right here on "The Beat." Trump`s impeachment trial is moving forward in the Senate. And some Democratic Presidential candidates will be taking their ideas out to the American public at the same time. That includes a push to address, what some call, the monopoly power of those big tech companies like Amazon or Facebook. Well, Senator Elizabeth Warren has been, of course, leading that fight. That`s something we spoke about in our interview on the day that she announced her plan to break up big tech this year. Take a look.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN (D-MA) PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: We need real competition in this field. And there`s a problem.

So Amazon, Google, they own a platform, which is pretty cool, right, where everybody comes to buy and sell or to do the searches. And at the same time, they own a bunch of businesses that are competing with all those folks who are coming, say, to Amazon in order to sell their goods. And they don`t just compete straight up.

They compete by being able to keep all of the information from every one of those companies and then decide, oh, I`m going after you and you and I know how much to charge and I know what kind of volume to expect. It`s a little like being an umpire in baseball and owning a team.

My view is you can do, one, be an umpire, or the other, my view is you can be one, be the umpire or, two, own a team. But you don`t get up to do both at the same time.

MELBER: Right. And you want to regulate so they don`t just favor themselves. You dropped this plan today. This is your first big TV interview about it.

Let`s take a look at some of the reception today.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Elizabeth Warren is going after big tech companies.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Warren rolling out one of her big policy plans, breaking up Amazon, Google and other big tech giants.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This is the toughest plan that we`ve seen to-date from any of the Democratic contenders.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: A huge shakeup in the tech sector.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: It`s big and it`s bold, and it`s going to be difficult to achieve.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Could she really force this kind of breakup?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MELBER: Could she really do it?

WARREN: You bet.

MELBER: What`s the answer?

WARREN: The answer is yes. But you know, let`s be really clear about this. If you still want to be able to search for coffee pots and look at 63 choices and get the one that`s going to be there in 48 hours, you can still do that as a consumer. This preserves the platform. If you still want to go on Google and find out the capital of North Dakota, you can totally do it.

What this is about is about competition. It`s about all those little businesses and startup businesses and entrepreneurs who want to put their products on Amazon or on Google and toward an enormous competitive disadvantage because Amazon or Google, if they like the money they see that you`re making because they get all the information, they decide to go into competition with you and put their product on page one and your product back on page six and kill your business.

MELBER: Let`s go to the way the Treasury Department is run because you look at it right now - I`ll draw your attention to a very simple illustration--

WARREN: OK.

MELBER: --under Donald Trump. We could put up on the screen. You have, in the red zone there, Goldman Sachs--

WARREN: Yes.

MELBER: --as part of Treasury Department leadership. If you go back, during the Obama era, we checked, and as you know, we had Goldman Sachs former executives running Treasury then. Go back to Bush, also Goldman Sachs. Go back to Bill Clinton, also Goldman Sachs.

In a Warren administration, would there be a former Goldman Sachs executive running the Treasury Department?

WARREN: Nope.

MELBER: Is that a pledge?

WARREN: Yes. Oh - that`s a--

MELBER: That`s a litmus test.

WARREN: Absolutely. But let me tell you why. The problem we`ve got right now is a revolving door between Wall Street and Washington that causes everybody to be on guess for - wait a minute. The next time this Treasury Secretary puts forward a proposal, is it because it really helps the economy, helps the American consumer, helps the American homeowner, or is it because it helps their former and possibly future employer?

Let`s just do for one second the Gary Cohn example, another Goldman Sachs. Do you remember?

MELBER: (inaudible).

WARREN: That`s exactly right. So Trump appoints Gary Cohn. He leaves Goldman Sachs. And Gary Cohn is going to have exactly one job, and that is to ramrod through a rewrite of the tax laws that will profoundly affect Goldman Sachs.

So what does Goldman Sachs do as Gary walks out the door? They hand him nearly a quarter of a billion dollars. It`s a gift. They don`t have to. It`s--

(CROSSTALK)

MELBER: Is it legal bribery?

WARREN: I think - I think of it as a pre-bribe.

MELBER: Pre-bribe.

WARREN: Yes. So Gary then goes out and guess what he does. He writes a tax law--

MELBER: Right.

WARREN: --and manages to help ramrod it through, that benefits Goldman Sachs to the tune of a quarter of a billion dollars in the first go-round.

MELBER: And what you`re saying--

WARREN: --and then it`s the gift that keeps on--

(CROSSTALK)

MELBER: What you`re saying makes sense, and we have such--

WARREN: Yes.

WARREN: --ripe targets. I think people could understand what you`re pointing to. But what does it mean for the Democratic Party if this was also how Obama and Clinton ran the Treasury. Would you be a fundamental break with that, I guess, is the question.

WARREN: The problem - I have written the biggest anti-corruption bill since Watergate because we have a fundamental problem in Washington. And understand, it`s a problem that pre-dates Trump by decades.

MELBER: Right.

WARREN: Trump may be the most extreme example now, the pre-bribes of Gary Cohn, for example. But we have a long standing problem, and that`s the influence of money on decision-making in Washington. So this bill has lots of pieces to it, including closing the revolving door between Wall Street and Washington, ending lobbying, as we know it, putting a real ethics cop on "The Beat" saying that the heads of these agencies cannot be trading in stocks--

MELBER: Right.

WARREN: --on individual stocks.

MELBER: So, as a political matter, are you basically writing off a bunch of Wall Street money and then today you`re writing off a bunch of Silicon Valley money.

WARREN: Maybe. But this isn`t about the money. This is about how it is we`re going to make this country work again, not just for the rich and the powerful, how are we going to make it work for everyone.

MELBER: Everyone has been talking about the rather light sentence that Paul Manafort got. When you look at that, does that reflect what you`re saying--

WARREN: Yes.

MELBER: --and Washington works well for the connected and the affluent and nobody else?

WARREN: Yes. It`s two justice systems. Look at the words carved above the United States Supreme Court. "Equal justice under law." But look at the reality. People who got buckets of money and are well connected kept traded with kid gloves.

MELBER: So do you think--

WARREN: Everybody else doesn`t.

MELBER: Do you think when you look at that statistically that a similar defendant who might have been born black would have gotten a different sentence?

WARREN: Oh. We know the data on this. Of course, the sentence would have been different. In fact, study after study after study shows that for the exact same crimes, African-Americans are more likely than whites to be arrested, to be prosecuted, to be arrested and wrongfully convicted and to receive harsher sentences. Race matters in our criminal justice system, and it is not a system of equal justice under law.

MELBER: I`ve got a couple of one-word associations. If you could do it in a word. Some of them relate to your bill.

WARREN: OK.

MELBER: Amazon.

WARREN: Can I have two words?

MELBER: Sure.

WARREN: Too big.

MELBER: Google.

WARREN: Too big.

MELBER: Facebook.

WARREN: Too big.

MELBER: Mark Zuckerberg.

WARREN: Too powerful. And that`s really the point of the too-bigs. It`s they`ve got too much power. And they get to use that power now to dominate markets, to chew up competitors, and ultimately to change the consumer experience. We`ve got to change that.

MELBER: Favorite song to work out to?

WARREN: Anything from Patsy Cline.

MELBER: Patsy Cline. Favorite--

WARREN: I love Patsy Cline.

MELBER: Favorite album or artist when you were growing up.

WARREN: Any of "The Beatles."

MELBER: "Beatles."

WARREN: Probably - probably "The White Album."

MELBER: Now, I`ve got to know your favorite Beatle.

WARREN: Oh, no, that`s not fair.

(CROSSTALK)

WARREN: It`s like asking your favorite child.

MELBER: I would guess - what do I know? I don`t know you that well. I would guess Lennon. George Harrison? Boom.

WARREN: Yes.

MELBER: Your dream running mate throughout history, living or dead, if you could pick a person that would run with you.

WARREN: Teddy Roosevelt.

MELBER: A Republican?

WARREN: Yes.

MELBER: Because he took on the trusts?

WARREN: Because he was brave. And he took on the trusts. And he didn`t care how many people were going to be mad about it. And he did it. This is what`s amazing, for the right reasons. It wasn`t just that they were big. It wasn`t just that they were dominating an economy. It wasn`t just that they were putting farmers out of business and competitors out of business and small companies out of business. It was that they had too much political power. And it was the very fact of that political power that caused Teddy Roosevelt to say, I`m going to be a trust-buster. Man, I`d like to have that guy at my side.

(LAUGHTER)

MELBER: There is a beloved actress who`s been talking about you, Annette Bening.

WARREN: Yes.

MELBER: Let`s take a look. I think we have this for you. Annette Bening says she knows she looks like Elizabeth Warren--

(LAUGHTER)

MELBER: --thank you very much. Now--

WARREN: Wow! I`m flattened.

MELBER: Does she look like you or do you look like her?

WARREN: Either way. I`m totally happy with this comparison.

MELBER: You like this?

WARREN: Yes, I do.

MELBER: Would you be comfortable - if and when there`s a Warren administration and then there`s a Warren movie, would you be comfortable with her playing you?

WARREN: I`m all in.

MELBER: You`re ready for that?

WARREN: I`m ready.

MELBER: We have to ask before we let you go, how Bailey is doing. This dog is beloved on your campaign.

WARREN: This dog is the best. Between the Bailey cam and the opportunity to meet people, and voters and people have been bringing him little treats. So Bailey is filling out now for a 10-month-old dog.

MELBER: And he has his own greeting line as well as you.

WARREN: Oh, man! He does a photo line like you wouldn`t believe. And I want to be really clear about this, Ari. It is not a competition.

MELBER: No.

WARREN: I say this because I definitely do not want to be in competition with a 10-month-old Golden Retriever.

MELBER: I`ve seen him. I`m a dog person myself. I`m sure he could get a lot of individual donors as well if he goes in that direction.

WARREN: That`s right.

MELBER: Senator Warren, coming here on the day of your big tech announcement, we really appreciate it. Hope you come back on "The Beat."

WARREN: Good.

MELBER: Thank you.

WARREN: Thank you.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MELBER: We`re going to show you a lot more ahead on this holiday special of "The Beat," including my conversation with Oscar-winning Director Lee Daniels, part of many of our "Mavericks" highlights.

MELBER: Welcome back to our holiday special. Over this whole year, some "Beat" viewers come up to me and say, what is the deal with all the music stuff? Some others of you have said, well, thank you for adding some culture into the news. And honestly, culture already is in our life and in our politics.

The only question in the newsroom is whether we face it or just ignore it. Artists often form our first view of things, whether it`s Bruce Springsteen or Bob Dylan making us think about America or Joni Mitchell and Muhammad Ali making us think about our foreign policy.

This year, I think we had our mind expanded by several artists on "The Beat." Take Lee Daniels, award-winning Director of "Precious," "The Butler," "Monster`s Ball," and the hit show, "Empire." He joined me for our "Maverick" series, discussing racism in life and Hollywood, why Donald Trump once asked him to direct a movie, and then this exchange that many of you have written in about.

Daniels opening up about the emotional moment when Halle Berry won an Oscar for a leading role in his film, "Monster`s Ball," in 2002.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MELBER: Where were you when Halle Berry was the first black woman to win an Oscar for a lead role in that movie?

LEE DANIELS, AMERICAN FILM WRITER, DIRECTOR & PRODUCER: I was in a hotel. You`ve clearly done your homework. Have you?

MELBER: I do some homework. All right. There you go.

DANIELS: Yes. I was in a hotel, inebriated.

MELBER: Not expecting to win then? Or inebriated regardless?

DANIELS: Not expecting to win at all. Invited, but not - I didn`t intend on - didn`t feel like I deserved to be there.

MELBER: Why not? You were part of the movie.

DANIELS: Oh, no. Because when Hollywood tells you you do not deserve it, you sort of believe that.

MELBER: What hotel?

DANIELS: The Chateau Marmont.

MELBER: Naturally. A little on the nose, Lee.

DANIELS: Oh, yes? Sort of. I didn`t think I was deserved being at the table. So I didn`t - I didn`t go there.

MELBER: So that`s something people who think of you as this successful culture-creating star, frankly, might be surprised that even at that point in your career, even on Oscar night, you weren`t in the room - as you put it, inebriated in a hotel, and then this happens.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: And the Oscar goes to Halle Berry in "Monster`s Ball."

HALLE BERRY, AMERICAN ACTRESS: I want to thank Lee Daniels, our producer. Thank you for giving me this chance, for believing that I could do it, and now, tonight, I have this.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DANIELS: That`s nice. I hadn`t seen that in forever. I hadn`t - think I saw it since that time and since the - since the Chateau Marmont.

MELBER: This is the first time you`re seeing it since that night. How does it look now?

DANIELS: It looks great. It makes me feel like I was just naive and stupid for not going. Yes.

MELBER: What brings the tears?

DANIELS: It`s a hard fight, a really hard fight. And she deserved it. Yes, she deserved it. It was a - that`s the first time I`ve seen that.

MELBER: She deserved it, but you didn`t think--

DANIELS: I deserved it? No, I didn`t think I deserved it. Yes, I was just doing another day - another day. I`m trying to think about what my next gig is at, where did my next gig is coming from and how I could change the world with the next piece of work that I could do. Something that was unexpected. So, she`s there. I`m in the bed with a crack pipe and thinking, OK, so what`s next for me? What - how do I - how do I change the world with the next piece of work that I want to create.

MELBER: How do you feel remembering that she thought you did deserve it and she thanks you from that stage?

DANIELS: See, you just don`t have time to take it in. You don`t have time. Life is so short that you just, ah, OK, thank you. You know? And you don`t really stop and take it in. And this time, I took it in. That`s why I became emotional. You`ll never see me cry on television again. That`s for sure.

MELBER: Yes?

DANIELS: Mm-mm (ph).

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MELBER: Mm-mm (ph). I don`t think we have since. Our thanks to Lee Daniels for that candid conversation. We`re also thankful to a legendary singer I know you know about, Annie Lennox. She took us on an unusual tour of an art exhibit, tracing her work and life at MASS MoCA museum. This is also part of our "Mavericks" interviews. And it touched on how she pushed boundaries on gender identity and feminism back in 1983 when she was out wearing men`s clothing and touring worldwide with eurhythmics.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MELBER: When you were coming up in eurhythmics, the reaction around the world was, wow, how can she dress like that, or does that mean she`s gay, or what does that say about gender? And you said - you`ve said at the time, you weren`t trying to be a gender-bender. So what were you trying?

ANNIE LENNOX, SINGER-SONGWRITER: I wanted to be a powerful performer. And I wanted to resonate to people in a certain way. And I definitely, by the time Dave and I formed eurhythmics, I definitely had the sense of who I was and what I wanted to do.

And it was in partnership with Dave, who`s a man, and the sense of being equals. We were almost like twins on the stage. Like, we were each other`s muse, if you`d like. That is powerful wear a man`s - I mean, I didn`t always wear a man`s suit. I wore all kinds of costumes. I mean, that was one way to perform that made people think and had a very, very strong, powerful image, if you like. If I broke rules, they were very restrictive.

MELBER: Many people remember you wearing this "HIV POSITIVE" shirt.

LENNOX: I hope people remember me. And I hope that that message did spread. As an advocate for HIV and AIDS, I wore that T-shirt or T-shirts like that with the messaging on the front, and at the back, it would say, fighting HIV and AIDS. I`m a mother. So I think it`s the fact that I`m a woman and a mother and have been a young girl. And I identify with women everywhere.

For me, my interpretation of feminism goes right around the globe because beyond the unseen boundaries of our western bubble lie the biggest challenges for girls and women around the globe that there, you know, those are the places where we need feminism, female empowerment more than anywhere else. There`s just such a huge gap that needs to be addressed. We need to understand feminism on a global basis.

I come from a working class background in Scotland. I thought I understood what poverty was. There was poverty around. When I went to visit these countries, when I saw what was happening, you see children in rags, you see children that cannot go to school, you see children that cannot eat. And that`s a population level because of poverty. You - you don`t - you realize that, oh, my God, I didn`t know what poverty meant. When you understand the scale of it, it is very, very life-changing.

We all have things, baggage. We`ve all got experiences. We`ve all got memories. A lot of them we need to let go off as well. And we go through those phases. I`m in this kind of older phase of my life where I`m reflecting a lot back. A lot of things are memory for me. I`ve kind of re- created them in this dream-scape which is (inaudible) let you go.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MELBER: That was really neat for us to spend some time there. And of course, it was her vision that propelled her to the top of the charts. We checked. They sold over 80 million records worldwide and worked on the activism you saw there.

The `80s were also a time of artistic inspiration and revolution right here in New York City, the foundation for shifts across the culture. That`s something we explored in my interview with two moguls from Def Jam Records, who helped make hip-hop mainstream, Kevin Liles and Lyor Cohen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KEVIN LILES, AMERICAN RECORD EXECUTIVE & CO-FOUNDER AND CEO, 300 ENTERTAINMENT: I believe rap music took on something from early rock-and- roll that said there`s a lot that we have to say. Remember, rap music was introduced on a corner and then maybe one hour every Friday night for a show.

LYOR COHEN, AMERICAN MUSIC EXECUTIVE: What was happening here in New York in the early `80s is fashion, art and rap music was bumping, colliding together. And the spirit of it was underpinned by affordable housing.

So the whole SoHo, where we are right now, was full of artists.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MELBER: Imagine that, Downtown New York being affordable. What he was talking about there was also of course including visual artists. And we heard about that in our series this year as well from producer Swizz Beatz. He`s working with artists like Kehinde Wiley to advance diversity in the often closed art world.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SWIZZ BEATZ, AMERICAN DJ, RECORD PRODUCER, ART COLLECTOR & ENTREPRENEUR: It`s something different to say I have Kehinde Wiley, and matter of fact, let me see if he`s around for dinner tonight. Right?

MELBER: Right.

BEATZ: It`s very important for us, as a culture, to own the culture or pieces of the culture and change that whole concept of making it for other people to own, and we don`t have a trace of it left around where we can pull from, which is the reason why we collect and the decollection so heavy. We collect like we`re building a museum because we wanted to save most of these pieces, so the next generation and the youth can have something to pull from or go back to - of the history.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MELBER: It`s living history. And those are just some of the topics we got to tackle on "Mavericks." I want to share with you, if you want to see more of those, there`s longer in-depth interviews, and they`re all posted at msnbc.com/mavericks. You can check them out now. We`re not done tonight though. Coming up, some of our favorite funny moments all across this year on "The Beat." It`s a highlight reel you don`t want to miss.

MELBER: How do you take stock of your year? Do you focus on the big stuff, the most intense memories, or maybe the goofy times that reminded you how much we`re all just people trying to make our way in this world? Well, around here, honestly, we obviously work on a television show. So many of our moments have been recorded for better or worse. And we`ve gathered them together to share with you. And a warning to viewers, brace yourself for some musical references, dad jokes and, yes, even - awkward silences.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Sit down because here it comes. "The Beat with Ari Melber" starts right now. Good evening, Ari.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: That`s it?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: That`s it, buddy.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: I really expected a rap lyric for this one, Ari.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Are you really majority leader, if you`re not running this like (inaudible).

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: To quote Jay-Z, when the gimmies (ph) in the system, ain`t no telling, will he love him or he diss (ph) him?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: To quote Killer Mike--

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: A line from Drake--

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Did Barr worked it? I think Barr flipped it and reversed it.

MELBER: Do you have any Killer Mike quotes for us, Bill?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Do I - do I not--

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: A wise man once said, "Nothing at all."

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Let me get on my back, Joe, and say, lean back and welcome David Brooks (ph) to the party.

MELBER: It`s getting hot in here. Maybe not you.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: No, no, I`m cold.

MELBER: Are you dropping precedence in your first answer?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I did. I`m sorry about that.

MELBER: It`s just got - just amazing.

You guys realize this is weird, right?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: It is super weird.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MELBER (voice-over): The awkward silences.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Oh.

MELBER: Let`s reflect on that.

I did want to let this moment--

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Sit.

MELBER: --sit.

I don`t know what can you say.

That`s how they know about the Martians who landed here.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: That`s just (ph) same time.

MELBER: Actually, I`m making a joke.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: OK.

MELBER: I`m going to end with my bad holiday joke--

(CROSSTALK)

MELBER: Are you saying the cattle industry had beef with Oprah?

(LAUGHTER)

MELBER: This is a holiday where you say, look, let my full report go.

(LAUGHTER)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I`m sorry.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Just come on.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Come on.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Come on.

(CROSSTALK)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This is - this is--

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Wait. I quit. No. Wait. Wait.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This is ending toxic masculinity right here.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MELBER: It all happened here. Thanks for being a part of it. We won`t soon forget it.

MELBER: Now, as far as we`re concerned around here, 2019 was not a normal year, and it wasn`t supposed to be because you can`t look at what`s been happening and act like it`s normal. So we`ve been doing our part night- after-night. We want to say thank you to the viewers for watching and supporting the journalism and what we do on "The Beat." We want to wish everyone, of course, a very happy new year.

And I want to thank our team because sometimes I get people coming up to me saying, and they say, wow, how`d you find this or that was so clear the way you explained and reported that. And the answer is, well, thank you, but it is a huge, huge team effort from everyone here in our headquarters at MSNBC and around the building and around the world. We want to say thank you to those who put this all together.

urn:contentItem:5WH3-RS81-JB20-G3KK-00000-00THE BEAT WITH ARI MELBER for July 5, 20192019-07-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:31:31ZLexisNexisTHE BEAT WITH ARI MELBER6:00 PM ESTJohn Feal, Vic Mensa, George Clinton, Nick KristofNEWSDomestic070501cb.457THE BEAT WITH ARI MELBER for July 5, 2019Ari Melber

THE BEAT looks on a special report on the evidence that Bob Mueller put on obstruction against Donald Trump, the cultural backlash with Donald Trump`s harsh immigration policies, an artist who`s made a huge statement imagining American children in those infamous cages. Ari Melber interviews a 9/11 first responder who teamed up with Jon Stewart, and they`re taking on Mitch McConnell. Jon Stewart is back at it blasting Mitch McConnell for what he says is just playing politics with 9/11 victims. Vic Mensa is rebuking the Trump administration policy on immigration by making the Camp America video.

ARI MELBER, MSNBC HOST: Good evening and welcome to a special edition of THE BEAT on this July 4th holiday weekend. I am Ari Melber tonight. The 2020 race obviously heating up candidates making all kinds of cases to voters around the nation. And I`m thrilled to tell you, we have interviews with top contenders about some of these issues. Also, on tonight`s show a special report on Donald Trump`s obstruction, the evidence that Democrats say will be key as Bob Mueller prepares to speak publicly about it for the very first time in this upcoming congressional hearing. So that`s a special report, we`re bringing you in tonight`s broadcast.

Also, later, we speak to a 9/11 first responder who`s teamed up with Jon Stewart taking on the most powerful Republican in Congress, an issue that remains unresolved. All that plus a very special fallback Friday. Pulitzer Prize winning columnist, Nick Kristof and Rock and Roll Hall of Famer, the one and only p funk legend George Clinton will join us later. So, we have a lot to get to, but we begin right here with the race that is heating up this summer right now 2020. And who is making the arguments to be the nominee to run against Donald Trump.

The Democratic presidential candidates are going big and all kinds of ways like criminal justice, inequality, taking on Wall Street. And that is part of where we began a recent interview with Senator Elizabeth Warren talking about breaking up big tech and how she wants to hold corporations accountable.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN (D-MA) PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: We need real competition in this field and there is a problem. So, Amazon, Google, they own a platform which is pretty cool, right, where everybody comes to buy and sell or to do the searches. And at the same time, they own a bunch of businesses that are competing with all those folks who are coming say to Amazon in order to sell their goods.

And they don`t just compete straight up, they compete by being able to keep all of the information from every one of those companies and then decide, oh I`m going after you and you and I know how much to charge and I know what kind of volume to expect. It`s a little like being an umpire in baseball. And owning a team.

My view is, you can do one, be an umpire or the other on a team, but you don`t have to do both at the same.

MELBER: Right and you want to regulate so they don`t just favor themselves. You drop this plan today. This is your first big TV interview about it. Let`s take a look at some of the reception today.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Elizabeth Warren is going after big tech companies.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Warren rolling out one of her big policy planks, breaking up Amazon, Google and other big tech giants.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: This is the toughest plan that we`ve seen to-date from any of the Democratic contenders.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: for a huge shakeup in the tech sector.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: It`s big and it`s bold and it`s going to be difficult to achieve.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Could she really force this kind of breakup?

MELBER: Could she really do it. What`s the answer?

WARREN: The answer is yes. But you know let`s be really clear about this. If you still want to be able to search for coffee pots and look at you know 63 choices, get the one that`s going to be there in 48 hours. You can still do that as a consumer. This preserves the platform. If you still want to go on Google and find out the capital of North Dakota, you can totally do it. What this is about is about competition. It`s about all those little businesses and startup businesses and entrepreneurs who want to put their products on Amazon or on Google and who are at an enormous competitive disadvantage because Amazon or Google, if they like the money they see that you`re making, because they get all the information, they decide to go into competition with you and put their product on page one and your product back on page six and kill your business.

MELBER: Your plan is enacted. Do each of those companies get somewhat broken up?

WARREN: So, what they get is, the platform gets broken off from the individual companies

MELBER: And you`re saying that`s good for consumers.

WARREN: It`s excellent for consumers because it not only means the platform will be level. You`re not getting something from Amazon pushed out in front of you and a better competitor hitting back on page six. It also means the next good idea has a chance to mature.

MELBER: Right. That Amazon just like everyone remembers, the booksellers is not going to be kneecapping everyone.

WARREN: That`s right.

MELBER: You`re here on THE BEAT tonight announcing this plan today and you`re campaigning in Long Island City.

WARREN: I am.

MELBER: Where Amazon just pulled out. Is that deliberate?

WARREN: That`s right. You bet, it`s deliberate.

MELBER: What are you saying?

WARREN: What I`m talking about is how big these tech giants have gotten so that what we see, and we saw right there on Long Island City is they come in, they bully towns, cities, states, all around the country. The handful of tech giants have gotten more than $10 billion in breaks from towns and cities and states over the past few--

MELBER: Corporate welfare.

WARREN: That`s right.

MELBER: So is that. Let me ask you this. Is that a problem with the incentives or was New York wrong to give them that much of an offer?

WARREN: The problem is The Hunger Games about it, because that`s what`s happening here and it`s a problem because it creates more concentration in the energy - in the industry. You know they`re not offering the cities and towns a zillion bucks and goodies and tax breaks to the entrepreneur who is getting started to the small business that`s trying to make a go of it even to the medium sized business and big business that want to grow more. No, this is about the giants who are able to swagger into town and say, play in front of me what you`re going to offer, and I`ll decide if I like it or not and then I`ll go somewhere else and see what they`ll offer. And by the way, if you start asking me hard questions about the jobs, about where the money is going to come from, about how much guarantee I`m putting into this. I`ll just get mad and go somewhere else.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MELBER: And here on THE BEAT we`ve been catching up with other candidates as well, including one who is pretty hot right now according to many political insiders that Senator Kamala Harris and she has a very specific plan to tackle inequality from a whole different angle. The gender pay gap.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. KAMALA HARRIS (D-CA) PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: What I am proposing is that we shift the burden away from that working woman and instead onto that corporation to prove that they`re paying people equally. There should be a consequence to the corporation if they`re not paying people equally for equal work. Women deserve to be paid as much as men and they are not.

MELBER: Right.

HARRIS: And this has not changed over decades. And so, we`re going to have to change the way that we`re approaching the issue and the way that I`m proposing we change it is that the corporations have to make it their business to investigate and do an analysis of how they`re paying people and then they have to report that information and then that woman or even a man and anybody--

MELBER: Right, it`s gender. So, whatever is unfair.

HARRIS: But whoever is applying for a job with that business or might be a consumer of the products of that business, they can look up the rating of that corporation and make a decision about whether they want to encourage good or bad behavior.

You know, you get -- you get to recapture your songwriters after a certain amount of years. They started to block those recaptures so they need to fall back on that, you know.

MELBER: And can I double down on your fallback?

CLINTON: Please do.

MELBER: I think and I`ve learned a little bit of music from the great musicians that have come on the show, they also these industry leaders need to fall back on taking advantage of young artists who are so eager to get a shot that they sometimes will sign almost any, they don`t know what they`re signing.

CLINTON: That`s exactly -- you said it just like I wanted to. I didn`t know I have that much time. But that`s exactly what I`m saying. And even after you get to the point where you need to recapture the music, they jump in and block that, all these artists that you say just signed those papers that they didn`t know what they were signing. They need to fall back on that.

MELBER: Nick, what`s on your mind?

KRISTOF: This summer marks the 30th anniversary of China crushing the tenement democracy movement protesters. And I was there on that Square when that happened. It haunts me. And the fact that China now won`t even allow a mention of June 4th of that date or of the democracy movement to just try to erase that history, it is time for it to the fallback and honor some of those students and workers I saw who fell on that square that night.

MELBER: One of the things that cynical people say is well, who cares in other countries especially people in charge they can do what they want. But why is it you say that actually some of these authoritarian regimes do care about the words and images that go around the world about them?

KRISTOF: I mean, one measure of how much China cares is that any T.V. in China is showing in this MSNBC right now is going to have this section delete it because they censor anything that can come into the country that refers to Tiananmen, to the massacre there the -- what they`ve done to the internet underscores that.

And you know, we`ve seen in other countries in Taiwan and South Korea massacres later become studied and become overturned and at some point that is going to happen to China, and I`m going to see a memorial go up in Tiananmen Square to those courageous students of 1989 and I -- that`s the story I really look forward to covering.

MELBER: Well, amen to that. In a way, both of you are today talking about free expression which is a human right and is so important to human beings. My fallback is a little lighter. Now, you remember Bob Marley. You used to talk about songs of freedom?

CLINTON: Yes. What`s that for?

MELBER: Well, we`ve got something going on with the Trump administration that if you haven`t heard about, you got to hear about. You know, fossil fuels are controversial. People think about environmental protection. And the Energy Department under Donald Trump, look at this, is now trying to rebrand fossil fuels as molecules of freedom.

Trump administration rebrands fossil fuels as molecules of U.S. freedom, Energy Department trying to rebrand gas. This is a little Orwellian I think and it reminds me of freedom fries.

CLINTON: Yes. That was -- wow, that was good.

MELBER: Do you remember that?

CLINTON: I was being (INAUDIBLE). Freedom fries.

KRISTOF: Trying to reframe fossil fuels, I mean, that is quite a stretch.

MELBER: And I know this is a branding president, and I know that some of his supporters said oh, he`s going to do for America what he did in business, right. But if what you do in business or policy is just try to hide things with words instead of dealing with them, that`s not going to last.

KRISTOF: You can produce carbon emissions or you can rebrand fossil fuels.

CLINTON: Well, if you go into bankruptcy a thousand times, that`s the nice brand.

MELBER: You don`t think he was as good at business as he says.

CLINTON: No, no, there are many bankruptcy.

MELBER: What else is on your fallback list?

CLINTON: Well, you know, I`m a painter. I like to paint. And they got this robot, this thing that`s going to become a new thing in here.

MELBER: Yes, he`s artificial intelligence and he gives real painter some people say a run for their money.

CLINTON: Yes, I mean, that -- he need to fall back because see, I paint, I painted my shoes, I`m just not getting into the art. And they going to make robots to do that? They doing everything else?

KRISTOF: They`re writing new articles.

MELBER: This is -- you get -- you get into a deep place. Can artificial intelligence make art, George, do you think?

CLINTON: I`m sure they can do anything you can think about. I`m thinking this can be done. Pretty much somebody will find a way to do it. And intelligence, it`s copied on the computer. I`m sure they`ll find a way to do it. It`ll be accepted. I`m waiting on the hologram to come and take my place now.

(CROSSTALK)

MELBER: A little Coachella hologram for you?

CLINTON: Yes, you know what I`m saying. Now, you going to have robots, you get robots taking your love ones from, you mate, they got all kind of robots in store for you.

MELBER: Let me tell you something. Nick is a little bit like some musicians where he`s a big shot but he also has a big heart, and you don`t always see that together.

CLINTON: Yes. But it works -- it works like that in the funk.

MELBER: What`s this?

CLINTON: This is the new one here.

MELBER: Oh wow. All right, these are your -- and this is everybody in the band too?

CLINTON: Yes, all the different band members.

MELBER: That`s fantastic.

MELBER: Which one should we give to Nick? I`ll give you one.

KRISTOF: To make you a little funkier.

MELBER: Give him one of them.

CLINTON: Which one is for you? Which one do you want, Nick? You pick it.

KRISTOF: Well, this is pretty funky? How`s that?

CLINTON: Well, you pick the funky one. He got funked. I would love to get you another one.

KRISTOF: I like that.

MELBER: All right, George and Nick, thank you.

CLINTON: Thank you.

MELBER: And we will be right back.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

MELBER: Thanks for spending some time with us here on THE BEAT on your July 4th holiday weekend. Wishing you and your family the best. Now, we will be back here live 6:00 p.m. Eastern on Monday for THE BEAT with Ari Melber.
